description:
V1, a 1997 Pontiac Grand Am, was traveling eastbound on a 4-lane, 2-way, dry asphalt
                        roadway in daylight conditions. V1 was traveling in lane one intending to turn right at a
                        T-intersection. V2, a 2005 Dodge Grand Caravan, was stopped for a red light in lane one in front
                        of V1 on the same roadway, also intending to turn right. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35
                        mph). The front of V1 contacted the back of V2. Both vehicles came to final rest off the south
                        road edge.


                        The driver of V1 was a 21-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between
                        18-32 kmph (11-20mph) prior to the crash. He had no health related problems and had taken no
                        medication prior to the crash. He was rested and traveling to a restaurant. He does not wear
                        corrective lenses. He was uninjured and refused treatment.


                        The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle
                        stopped. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, an
                        external distraction, because he stated that he was looking at approaching traffic to his left
                        and did not realize that the vehicle ahead of him had stopped.


                        The driver of V2 was a 70-year old male who had reported that he had been stopped at the red
                        light prior to the crash. He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to
                        the crash. He was rested and traveling to a restaurant. He was wearing corrective lenses for
                        astigmatism. He was uninjured and refused treatment.


                        The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in
                        same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not
                        coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.
